description: Smallest prime with Hamming weight n (i.e. with exactly n 1's when written in binary).
comments: a(n) = 2^n - 1 for n in A000043, so Mersenne primes A000668 is a subsequence of this one. Binary length of a(n) is given by A110699 and the number of zeros in a(n) is given by A110700. - _Max Alekseyev_, Aug 03 2005Drmota, Mauduit, & Rivat prove that a(n) exists for n > N. [_Charles R Greathouse IV_, May 11 2010; corrected May 17 2010]A000120(a(n)) = A014499(A049084(a(n))) = n. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Feb 10 2013
links: T. D. Noe and Charles R Greathouse IV, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..3320 (first 1024 terms from T. D. Noe)
Michael Drmota, Christian Mauduit, and Joel Rivat, Primes with an average sum of digits, Compositio Mathematica 145 (2009), pp. 271-292.
MathOverflow, Are there primes of every Hamming weight?

example: The fourth term is 23 (10111 in binary), since no prime less than 23 has exactly 4 1's in its binary representation.
maple: with(combstruct); a:=proc(n) local m,is,s,t,r; if n=1 then return 2 fi; r:=+infinity; for m from 0 to 100 do is := iterstructs(Combination(n-2+m),size=n-2); while not finished(is) do s := nextstruct(is); t := 2^(n-1+m)+1+add(2^i,i=s); # print(s,t); if isprime(t) then r:=min(t,r) fi; od; if r<+infinity then return r fi; od; return 0; end; seq(a(n),n=1..60); # _Max Alekseyev_, Aug 03 2005
